title: index
content: Welcome This is the site for a notsosecret seminar on mathematics organized by a couple of secondyear math CS students at the University of Waterloo We meet every Friday

title: Upcoming Talks
content: MathJaxHubConfig extensions tex2jaxjs jax inputTeX outputHTMLCSS tex2jax inlineMath displayMath processEscapes true HTMLCSS availableFonts TeX Topic Speaker Location Time Talks on Wednesday October 12 2016 Primer on Algebra and Number Theory Fengyang Wang MC 4020 1730 This talk will cover the basics of group theory focusing especially on transformation groups commutator subgroups and solvable groups We will additionally cover some ideas from number theory like quadratic reciprocity Eulers totient function and the Legendre and Jacobi symbols Please message me in advance if there are any other subjects in particular that you would like me to discuss AbelRuffini Theorem Akshay Tiwary MC 4020 1830 The AbelRuffini Theorem is a famous result that not all polynomials with degree five or greater admit roots that can be described with only the elementary functions and radicals This talk will prove the AbelRuffini through elementary means Ultrafilters Felix Bauckholt MC 4020 1930 Talks on Friday October 14 2016 Information Theory Sidhant Saraogi TBD 1730 Required reading Stirlings Approximation PDF Types and ObjectOriented Programming Nikita Kapustin TBD 1830 Talks on Friday October 21 2016 Category Theory Luthfi Mawarid MC 4020 1730 Quantum Computing Michael Pang MC 4020 1830 Talks on Friday October 28 2016 Hacking Rolina Wu MC 4020 1730 Integration Gregory Patchell MC 4020 1830 Introduce the ideas that lead to the Lebesgue definition of the integral stressing on understanding rather than rigourous details Talks on Friday November 4 2016 Game Theory Koosha Totonchi MC 4020 1730 Symmetric Groups Randy Lin MC 4020 1830 Talks on Friday November 11 2016 Graphs Surfaces and Homology Kai Rsch MC 4020 1730 Random Graphs and Complex Networks Freida Rong MC 4020 1830 Talks on Friday November 18 2016 Hypercomplex Numbers Fengyang Wang MC 4020 1730 We all know that mathrmi21 But what if it werent This talk explores generalizations of the complex numbers
